subtitle: I'm happy to announce that March 1st is the official release date of the New Thinking
Allowed magazine's first quarterly issue.
You can download free PDF copies from the
website of the New Thinking Allowed Foundation.
If you like a high-quality printed edition as a
collectible, you can order it from magcloud.com.
Hello
and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
We'll be looking at training anomalous cognition
today. With me is Dr. Ed May, who is the
co-author of Anomalous Cognition, Remote Viewing, Research and Theory.
He is also the co-author of ESP Wars, East and West, and the co-editor of a two-volume
anthology called Extrasensory Perception, Support, Skepticism and Science.
In addition, he has received a lifetime career
award from the Parapsychology Association
and he has been the research director for
over a decade for the US Military Intelligence
Psychic Spying Program, commonly known as Project Stargate.
Welcome, Ed.
Thank you, Jeffrey.
Pleasure to be here.
Pleasure to be with you once again.
Your interest in training remote viewing abilities,
or anomalous cognition, is primarily from
the perspective of a researcher, which you are.
Yes, but it had its origin in the fact the Army wanted to train military personnel so
they could just recruit troops and train them
to be remote viewers and have an automatic
remote viewing unit in the Army.
An admirable goal, from my point of view, and some were.
They did engage in a training program.
Well part of training comes down to a definitional problem.
What do you mean by training?
I'm not a good speed runner and is it possible
to train me to run a four minute mile?
Well I don't have the native ability to run a four minute mile.
You know, if I could do a six minute mile, I'm really doing well.
All the training in the world would never get me to that goal.
So what appears by looking at other kinds of training, tennis, football, you name it,
the best you could do is train someone to reach their inherent native ability.
And like any other training situation, people have a wide range of skills.
Some are better at poker, some are better at running, some are better at jumping and
so on, and not everybody has the same level of skill.
And the trouble, I should think, with remote
viewing or anomalous cognition is that we
don't even really quite know what it is, how
it works at all, how to train something that's
so unknown.
Exactly.
In fact, that's frustrating.
If we try a particular training methodology and it fails, we don't know why it failed.
Maybe it failed because the people we were training had no psychic ability whatsoever.
Or maybe they had brilliant psychic ability and the training methodology was all wrong.
In fact, even if the training works, you don't necessarily know why.
Yeah, why did we even try that?
But the serious part of it is we wanted to
train for both research, in other words, can
we find people who in fact can do this
marvelous phenomenon known as remote viewing?
That was the goal.
And I have to tell you, we failed at that particular goal.
If you look at Professor Jessica Uttz, a statistician
of note, analyzed all the work that was done
at remote viewing and training at SRI International,
and her final conclusion is we have no evidence
in support of training.
Well, that's a conclusion that stands in contrast
to the many different organizations that offer
instruction and training in remote viewing,
some of which is offered at a very high price
with many promises.
I could make some pretty nasty comments about
that, but the serious issue is that all those
people who are offering those are well-met.
I'm not questioning their motivations.
But they're not aware of what is now
available online, the training methodologies.
And so I'm not sure if I had some money and
asked, well, should I take some well-meaning
army personnel who has no advanced degrees at all in any science whatsoever, why would
I pay that individual to teach something as complex as remote viewing training?
That's a question.
Well, many people aren't thinking along those lines.
You pretty much needed an advanced degree
in science to appreciate what another person
with an advanced degree can offer.
Nonsense.
I don't buy that story at all.
First of all, if you're going to produce a product of any kind, is there a market for
that product?
In this case, there's a huge market.
Because in some sense, frankly, it's a little bit misleading.
Instead of saying, we will find out what your
native skill level is and help you to reach
that skill level, I would be in support of that.
Instead, the implication is, although it's
not explicitly said, well, we will teach you
to be like Joe McMonagle, the best remote viewer on the planet.
And that's a lot of people have that expectations.
And we get calls from people who've gone through
a training methodology you can get online
or what have you, and they call us up in tears
because they go home and want to show remote
viewing to their relatives and they can't do it.
Well, let's talk about some of the problems that exist.
I think the situation may be even worse because
many times Joe McMonagle, who is a wonderful
person and very skilled and someone you've worked with closely for decades, but people
have a false understanding of what he can do.
They say, well, this guy's 100% accurate.
Well, he's never been 100% accurate.
One of our other remote viewers, because it's
a funny story, if you're looking at remote
viewing training, you have to worry about what are good targets.
And here is a particularly awful target, a tree in a dirt path.
Because if you close your eyes and imagine
in a remote viewing session you get an image
of a tree in a dark path, you think, there's
got to be something more there, so you're
filling in a lot of empty blanks that aren't there.
So I was sitting with this fellow, his name is Nevin Lance, a marvelous remote viewer,
and we started the session and he said, hmm,
I'm getting a tree and a path, that's it.
It was over in two seconds, and it was 100% correct in that example.
So he knew when to stop.
He knew when to stop.
That's not an easy thing.
But, okay, so if you have somebody, the issue
about training, for sure, you cannot train
anybody.
If I'm sitting in front of you as your trainer
and I'm looking at the target that I'm training
you on, and an awful lot of the training
methodologies use that action error, it got worse.
And this was Ingo Swann's great idea based on what's called operant conditioning.
In other words, I want to give you feedback immediately so you'll embed the experience
when you get it right.
The idea was marvelous, and Ingo deserves a lot of credit for that.
Mediate feedback is a good idea.
That sounds good idea.
But here I go.
I've got a picture here, Jeffrey, and you say waterfall.
You say water, and I say correct.
Now you're not going to start telling me about
a pyramid in the desert now because you're...
No, because you're giving me visual cues.
Not only that, verbal cues, I told you what, it's water.
And then you say a camel, and I don't say anything.
So I'm already giving you what turns out to be
like the old game on radio called 20 questions.
And it's not anything at all associated with sight.
So a person might go through a training program
like that and appear to be doing very good,
but actually they're just reading the cues.
Right.
Well, if I'm not even giving you intermediate
feedback at all, and you say water and I lean
slightly forward, and you say camel and I lean slightly back, that's nonverbal cues.
And there's been a great deal of research
of, what do you call it, expectation effects
by the researcher in standard psychology.
And so I can telegraph to you by encoding what I expect to have happen, and if you're
a good decoder of my nonverbal communication,
that drives the system, not remote viewing.
Even in daily life, I understand maybe 80% of the information that we communicate is
nonverbal.
Yeah, of course.
In fact, there's an interesting idea.
When we look at each other, we involuntarily
scan what looks to me as the right side of
your face.
That's your left side.
And that left side of your face is primarily
muscularly controlled by the right side of
your brain.
Right.
And that's a recognition of your emotional state.
So involuntarily, I'm learning what your state is by scanning that.
By the way, dogs do that to humans as well, but not to any other species.
There's a lot of research, I understand, about
how people can get in sync with each other
if they're just near each other at very subtle,
microscopic, physiological levels that start
to synchronize.
We're social beasts.
And that may appear to be some kind of ESP, but it's not.
I don't think so.
And so the main thing about ESP in training remote viewing, there's a misassumption out
there that it can be perfect.
Frankly, getting information by remote viewing
is as bad as the California telephone system.
The fact that it works as well as it does is a miracle unto itself.
The problem is people would like to be able to read by remote viewing.
They'd like to be able to get the combination of the lockdown at the bank.
And that's just beyond the capability that we currently understand that remote viewing
can do.
Or people say, if you're so smart, how come you aren't rich?
Why not win the Powerball lottery?
Well, there's a good technical answer to that.
There's not enough information sitting for
five hours that you can get by remote viewing
is to find out six double digit numbers.
It just doesn't happen.
And that's involving information theory and
a lot of stuff well beyond what we're talking
about.
No, things that you as a physicist have actually looked into.
Of course.
You were speaking from having made that inquiry.
Exactly.
Yeah.
So, there's a couple of things here.
People often in the public have a misimpression
of what they ought to be able to accomplish
with remote viewing.
What you're saying is that there's a lot of
hype out there, and so people need to be aware
that it works really well.
You've worked with the best remote viewers around for decades.
I'm sure you've seen some amazing hits.
I haven't.
I've seen some amazing failures as well.
So, people need to appreciate that.
Well, on the other hand, we all use our intuition.
Maybe that's another name, a synonym for remote viewing.
And there are people maneuvering through life.
You remember the book in the 70s, Executive ESP?
Yes, indeed.
And taking a bit of poetic license.
Basically, successful executives use their ESP even though they don't believe in it.
And it's part of the, you know, if you're
going to make a decision in absence of data,
what you do is you try to use your experience,
your intuition, everything, and we think,
as Douglas Dean thought, maybe a little ESP will sneak in there.
So, if I were doing succession planning and
I had two competitors to be the next CEO and
they were equal in all elements, I would choose the guy that did well in psyche.
The person that did well in psyche.
That makes sense.
But now, the other problem that you're saying
is that some of the programs that are out
there today and were even used within the
US military intelligence system for training
remote viewing were based on some faulty scientific assumptions.
I think so.
Now, there's a vigorous spirited debate on that with some of these people.
And part of it, in goes one, which is the basis of a lot of that training, which was
misinterpreted in my view, my opinion.
I've never seen an individual work harder than
he, including myself, that tried to understand
this marvelous experience he had as a marvelous remote viewer.
And he was not science trained, had a very high IQ, and he would spend 12 to 14 hours
a day at the library at Stanford reading about
all the operating conditioning and technical
things.
The problem came with he wanted to give us
intermediate feedback, and that was a disaster.
And that was instilled somehow in some of the early trainees of the army.
Well, I know that some of the hypnotic training
for ESP, some of Milan Ryzl's early work
in hypnosis involved something similar, and the
idea was to help build up people's confidence.
Sure.
And I think that's important.
I forget who was it, Bachelore that did the fake table laving?
Yeah.
And, you know, to build the confidence.
I think that's really important.
I don't mind that.
It's an old shamanistic trick.
Yeah, and it works wine.
But sometimes you stop it and get on to the
real science, and for some reason, Ingo never
made it that far.
There were some jewels of wisdom in Ingo's training, based on what I like to think of
as a word association test in psychology.
You know, you're faking it.
I'm your therapist, and you're trying to tell
me what you think I want you to say, right?
So on a word association test, I try to get
you, I say big and you say some word without
thinking about it.
I get a little insight into what's going on in your head.
And that was brilliant on Ingo's part, that he gives a stimulus like the geographical
coordinates or we currently use the word target.
And I want to know the first thing that pops into your mind, don't think about it.
So in a training session or in an actual remote
viewing session, I'll say, OK, Jeffrey, target,
give me the response.
And I see you going, hmm, I say, break, no more.
I don't want to hear what you're pondering,
because you can't reach the answer biological
inference.
I want to hear what you're doing when you're hesitating.
And that was brilliant on Ingo's part.
Well, I recall speaking just a week ago to
Joe McBonigle about training, and I know you
and Joe share many of these same viewpoints.
He suggested that what we're training is really
useful is to help people unlearn the habits
that we have that block our functioning.
Exactly.
And I completely agree.
You know, if I were saying if someone wanted
to be trained to remote viewer, I'm not a
shill for his books, but I would recommend buying remote viewing secrets.
And the most thing that he writes about in that are things that you shouldn't do.
It's to unlearn things and a few tips.
Let's take an example.
Suppose you were born on Mars and never, ever,
ever heard of a racquet game, how to play
tennis or squash or anything like that.
And I bring you down to Earth, and I have a net and a racquetball and a ball.
I'm a tennis ball and a tennis racquet.
And I say, your job, oh, Mr. Martian, is to
use this funny looking thing to get the round
thing on the other side of the fence.
You've never heard of a racquet.
And so you think, oh, well, to make sure I
can grip that funny looking thing, I'll grip
it at the business end, what we think of the
business end, and so I can have a good hit
on it.
And I said, no, no, let me give you a tip.
Switch it.
Grab the small end.
Is that training or is that a tip?
I don't know.
In fact, training methodology is very difficult
when you look at it through that perspective.
And what I think Joe does in that book is to give tips rather than training.
And it allows you to reach whatever native skill level you have.
Well, so much of remote viewing from people
who have been through the variety of programs
that seem to have been spin-offs from the military work is about protocols.
So many different things that you, first you
look at the overview, then you look at the
particular objects, then you take another look at the objects.
Well, that came from Ingo.
And we had, I think, three separate different
training tracks of which Ingo was one of them.
And so we had tried a whole lot of other ones.
One of the really good remote viewers had a blink test training.
You know, you close your eyes, open it up, close them again, and describe the picture
we were holding in front of your face.
And to get the idea, you know, one issue that people think happens, don't.
It doesn't happen.
And that is you close your eyes, you get a multimedia extravaganza and high definition
between your ears, and all you got to do is describe it.
No, no, that's not what's going to happen.
Wish that it would.
Oh, boy.
No kidding.
So in this case, that blink test was to get people used to having almost a subliminal
experience and being able to describe that.
That was an interesting training methodology.
It didn't work very well, but it was an interesting idea.
And that's what led Jessica and us to come to
the conclusion we could not support because
we didn't have a good definition of what we meant by training.
So what you can do is help provide people with tips.
You can help provide people with a supportive social environment.
Absolutely critical.
People with whom they can communicate and
share experiences and who will encourage them
and not say that they're crazy for even thinking this is possible.
That's really important.
Let me give you an example.
One of the things in what we called operational
research, in other words, how can we make
the spine better rather than understanding the phenomenon.
We looked at things like lucid dreaming and we looked at hypnosis.
Because we had a lot of resources, we hired
Stanford University's top experimental hypnotist.
And he came to do this.
And one of the things we looked at, long story
short, is that it was successful only to the
degree that the hypnotist and the remote viewer got along with each other.
I happen to know a woman very well in Hungary.
Her name is Eva Baniai and she was head of the
world hypnosis society and just a brilliant
woman in terms of hypnosis.
And I was in Hungary talking to her one day
and I said you know the only thing we figured
out was that the relationship, the interpersonal
relationship between the hypnotist and the
person being hypnotized and she said well it's about time you figured out.
We've known that for years and I felt like an idiot.
But rapport, working with people with whom you have good rapport is very important.
And that's true in remote viewing too.
And Russell Targ had absolutely a most magnificent ability to do that.
He can coax ESP out of a rock.
What are some of the other pitfalls in training?
The biggest pitfall I think is expecting
something more vigorous than it actually happens.
Even Joe says this, you know sometimes it feels like just a wild guess.
Go with it.
I should think patience is very important in this work.
I don't know.
That's an interesting question because remote
viewings can happen in a few seconds like
this is a train of path I quit.
And sometimes we work a problem for days in an
operational case like tunnels in some foreign
country and we'd go after it over and over and over and over again.
But how, and Russ found early on when they were doing narrative remote viewing after
outbound sites, I was the judge in a lot of
those cases, you know ten pages of transcripts.
I'd throw nine of them away and make the decision based on the first page.
Because once you get there, the problem is
we humans are great at filling in the details
that aren't there.
And so that's one avoidance.
Don't spend a lot of time on quick, bright and breezy and not ponderous.
Well you have a reputation as being an excellent judge.
I am.
Yourself.
And half of remote viewing besides the viewing is the judging.
I'll tell you where I'm a terrible judge.
The reason I'm a good judge is because I've
been working with the same people for 30 years.
So I know their individual idiosyncrasies.
And these people, unlike normal remote viewing
out in the real world, these people have been
trained because our tasking was to tell us what the target is and not what it reminds
them of.
Because if we want to save, find a kidnap victim, I'm sorry the fact that it reminds
you of your apple pie your mother used to bake, that's completely useless for me.
In other words, I guess that's called analytical overlay.
Well no, but that's the question we want them to give us.
Don't tell me what you think it is.
Tell me what, no, don't tell me what it
reminds you of, tell me what you believe it is.
Now in the Gonsfeld for example, Kathy Dalton
had a 40% hit rate in the Gonsfeld at Edinburgh
and she asked me to do the judging.
I scored it at chance.
The reason being is it was all kind of allegorical
and what it reminded the individuals, I did
not know how to judge that.
I see, but that was necessary in her case.
In their case, yeah.
Because the methodology, the tasking was different.
Here and it's very narrow and that's why I'm a good judge.
I judge an awful lot of remote viewings, but
with people who know that they are only to
give me what will help me as a judge separate out among the possibilities.
What the target is, not what it's like.
So it removes from my judging as much subjectivity on my part as possible.
It makes the job much easier.
And in Kathy Dalton's experiment, the opposite was the case.
Exactly.
That was really insightful for me to be able
to fail categorically, but I wasn't the judge
of choice.
It was a secondary case.
Because a skeptic could go through and say she
must have misjudged it if you can't replicate
the judging.
Well, not every judge who judges the Olympics gives the same score.
So you know, judges are human too, although
we had a kangaroo in our group, no we didn't.
But there's a big subjective element to so much of this remote viewing.
That's right.
And the other thing is that even a great viewer
like Joe has to go through periods when he's
just not getting much.
Oh, I've seen many of those periods.
I have a sort of a qualitative number of his
success rate over the years, where 20% is
chance he's running at 48%.
And that means he has some spectacular failures.
Yeah, even like a great baseball player like
a Babe Ruth who struck out more than he hit
home runs.
That's right.
Exactly.
That's a great analogy.
I'm going to steal it from you.
You're very welcome.
You're very welcome to that.
But one of the points that Joe made is that he became a good remote viewer because the
military paid him to do it, so that he would
kind of slog through it and stick with it
even when it was discouraging.
Yeah, because that's what he was being paid
for and his whole career was in a sense ruined.
That was the only option to him left in the
military because he got assigned to this unit
and he could no longer be assigned to any other unit to do any other thing.
But these days, very few people, especially while they're in their learning phase, are
not going to be paid.
No, that's true.
So, they're going to have to persevere through
periods when it looks like nothing of any
significance is happening.
Well, Putoff and Target explored what inducements
you can get to get people to do well, M&M's
or paying.
Turns out none of that seemed to work, so it seems to have worked for Joe only.
I'm not sure.
My reward for doing it as a researcher, I'm
absolutely fascinated by beginning as a physicist
to figure out some aspect of reality that all of us have overlooked in the past.
That's thrilling.
Yeah.
And somebody pays me to do that?
They're crazy.
I love it.
Well, you've come up with some very significant
findings, maybe not a huge wealth, but a handful
of important findings.
We've been discussing and we will continue
to discuss, but I think from this particular
interview about training, one of the takeaways
is that if one were to go through all the
data that was collected about training during
the 20 years of military intelligence work
in remote viewing, the bottom line is that the training per se, you don't have data to
show it succeeded.
Yes, by the definition of training.
That said, however, we would tell you that if you want to try to learn remote viewing,
buy a simple book and go with your gut.
And that's easy.
And maintain the protocol.
The protocol means, in this case, that no one else in the world knows the target who
is sitting in front of you.
Maintain a double blind.
You absolutely must do a double blind or you're fooling yourself.
Ed May, thank you once again for being with me.
Well, always.
It's great fun, Jeffrey.
Thank you.
And thank you and enlightening for me also.
And thank you for being with us.
